about_text.value: Three souls share a sealed parlor that is equal parts drawing room and oubliette. They test each other with confessions, blame, and bargains, and the room itself never changes. Every choice is a negotiation of pride, cruelty, and the thin hope of escape.

text_script.value: The room breathes without lungs, and the furniture insists on itself. Each of you fills the silence with the story you prefer, then flinches when the other two refuse to play along. The light never warms, but it exposes everything. A half-truth becomes a weapon, and you decide whether to disarm or press in.

prompt_script.value: Choose how to press or soften the room.

text_script.value: Press the confession.

The room tightens as the admission hangs in the air, and the others use it the way they use everything else: as leverage. You feel the weight of their belief as much as the truth itself. You force the issue, asking for a concrete admission. You measure the damage, then decide who it should belong to next.

The room accepts the truce only as long as it is useful, and you sense the bargain fraying at the edges the moment it is spoken. You force the issue, asking for a concrete admission. You measure the damage, then decide who it should belong to next.

The deflection buys you a moment, but it also teaches the others which parts of you are thin and which are armored. You force the issue, asking for a concrete admission. You measure the damage, then decide who it should belong to next.
Offer a truce.

The room tightens as the admission hangs in the air, and the others use it the way they use everything else: as leverage. You feel the weight of their belief as much as the truth itself. You suggest a temporary ceasefire, if only to breathe. You measure the damage, then decide who it should belong to next.

The room accepts the truce only as long as it is useful, and you sense the bargain fraying at the edges the moment it is spoken. You suggest a temporary ceasefire, if only to breathe. You measure the damage, then decide who it should belong to next.

The deflection buys you a moment, but it also teaches the others which parts of you are thin and which are armored. You suggest a temporary ceasefire, if only to breathe. You measure the damage, then decide who it should belong to next.
Change the subject.

The room tightens as the admission hangs in the air, and the others use it the way they use everything else: as leverage. You feel the weight of their belief as much as the truth itself. You deflect into a safer story or a sharper accusation. You measure the damage, then decide who it should belong to next.

The mirror is honest but selective, showing only what you will not admit. Garcin watches for approval, Inez watches for weakness, Estelle watches for a verdict she can survive. Every glance suggests a verdict anyway. You can either trap each other in a narrative or concede a fragment of it.

The locked door is not a barrier so much as a question. It is the only object in the room with a clear purpose, and yet it refuses to answer. You decide whether the only way out is agreement or whether the only agreement is to stay and punish one another.

The door hums without opening. You feel the others watching you for weakness or mercy, and each gaze invents a separate verdict. Staying is a decision, leaving is a decision, and the room will accept whichever story you agree to perform together. The air thickens as you realize the choice is not about escape but about who must forgive.
Accept that hell is other people.
The decision settles and the room accepts the story you chose. You feel the others register it, not as truth, but as a rule you will all be forced to live by for the next stretch of silence.
Two of you agree to leave together.
The decision settles and the room accepts the story you chose. You feel the others register it, not as truth, but as a rule you will all be forced to live by for the next stretch of silence.
All three agree to leave together.
The decision settles and the room accepts the story you chose. You feel the others register it, not as truth, but as a rule you will all be forced to live by for the next stretch of silence.
The room refuses any real decision.
The decision settles and the room accepts the story you chose. You feel the others register it, not as truth, but as a rule you will all be forced to live by for the next stretch of silence.

You accept the verdict. The room is not a prison but a mirror held too close, and leaving would require a kindness none of you can offer. The light stays on. The three of you remain, rehearsing the same confession until it is a ritual and the ritual is the only proof you ever existed at all.

A fragile pact forms. Two of you step toward the door not as allies but as survivors who can tolerate each other?s gaze. The third stays behind, watching the light change without following. The room gives you a narrow exit, and the new silence feels as dangerous as the old accusation.

For a breath, the room loosens. You name each other without cruelty, and the door opens as if it has been waiting for a single shared thought. All three of you step out together, aware that agreement is temporary but real, and that mercy has its own cost. The corridor beyond does not promise salvation, only the chance to begin again without the room's glare.

The room refuses to resolve. Each of you blames the others for the lock, and the conversation collapses into the same spiral. The door remains closed, and the argument becomes the only motion left. You realize the room is satisfied as long as you keep circling. The silence between accusations becomes another kind of prison, softer but no less total.
